In Paramount‚Äôs first ALL-TALKING Western, themes of loyalty, justice, and love are explored through the title character's complex relationships with his friend (Richard Arlen,) his nemesis (Walter Huston), and a school teacher (Mary Brian.) Coop's portrayal of the stoic, morally upright cowboy helped define the Western hero archetype in the decades that followed.

Reception: The film was well-received at the time of its release and has since been regarded as a classic. It was praised for its performances, particularly Cooper's, and its ability to bring the novel's themes to life on screen.

Transition to Sound: "The Virginian" was made during the transition from silent films to "talkies." As Gary Cooper's first sound film, it showcased his ability to adapt to the new demands of sound cinema, including delivering dialogue and using his voice effectively.

Legacy: "The Virginian" has been remade several times, including a 1946 version and a television series from 1962 to 1971. However, the 1929 version remains notable for its historical importance and role in launching Gary Cooper's sound film career.

Overall, "The Virginian" (1929) is a landmark film that not only highlights Gary Cooper's early talent but also represents an essential moment in the evolution of the Western genre and the film industry's transition to sound.

sources.title: The Virginian (1929)
sources.description: I've been researching newly public domain films from 1929 and earlier, so I'm uploading the best possible copies that I can find. One of the first Western films that was fully voiced, The Virginian was a massive success for its stars and director Victor Fleming. Even today the techniques used for sound synchronization and the use of outdoor filming are frequently praised. Critics at the time of release were exceptionally pleased by the film, although modern reviews are more lukewarm.¬†

metadata.Plot: Molly Wood arrives in a small western town to be the new schoolmarm. The Virginian, foreman on a local ranch, and Steve, his best fiend, soon become rivals for her affection. Steve falls in with bad guys led by Trampas, and the Virginian catches him cattle rustling. As foreman, he must give the order to hang his friend. Trampas gets away, but returns in time for the obligatory climactic shootout in the streets.
